description._content: Image from the National Media Museum Collection. The American Charles Urban came to London in 1897 to manage a film and equipment company. He quickly made the Warwick Trading Company, the leading firm in the first decade of British cinema. In 1901 Urban persuaded Warwick to finance Turner’s work for six months. Despite no positive outcome, Urban was willing to risk his own money on Turner’s invention and bought out Lee’s interest. Urban turned to the brilliant Brighton-based engineer, Alfred Darling, to produce a camera, projector and perforator based on Turner’s idea. Click on to the next picture to find out what happened next. We're happy for you to share this digital image within the spirit of The Commons. Certain restrictions on high quality reproductions of the original physical version of apply though; if you're unsure please visit the National Media Museum website. For obtaining reproductions of selected images please go to the Science and Society Picture Library.
